review_title: eCornell trashing the ivy league status of Cornell University.
pros: The benefits offered are good.
cons: As an eCornell employee, I can attest to the negative reviews. A very chaotic and stressful environment where even doing your best isn't good enough. Top leadership is destroying the ivy league reputation of the university by using deceitful and poor business and marketing practices that potential students would only equate with a lesser caliber school. Instead of upper management accepting failure of their poor strategies, middle management is posed to create an intimidating and unproductive environment in an attempt to "grow numbers". Recently after becoming endowed employees of the university itself, many employees who were misclassified under the FLSA are now taking yet another financial hit by being paid less monthly due a pay restructuring. At no time has anyone taken responsibility for the incredible amounts of overtime that was worked by misclassified employees in an attempt to keep up with changing demands - where back pay is legally due. However, we have now had our workload increased significantly to try to meet absurd goals that are unobtainable even under the best of conditions. Because of this, many employees are forced to work off the clock and through breaks to avoid general upset from management as your "numbers" are put under a magnifying glass for the entire organization to see. While management strictly enforces the rules of "no overtime" it is impossible to complete work as assigned under the constant stress, distractions, changing strategies and leadership who uses fear and intimidation due to an inability and clear lack of experience. In an attempt to avoid backlash, employees simply do not voice their concerns or record their time accurately as they are afraid they will be terminated or retaliated against. If you like constant criticism, belittling and threats of intimidation all while being placed under a microscope having all daily activities monitored, examined and exploited to the 10th degree this is your place to work.  Someone else mentioned upward mobility. There is none unless you're favored immensely.

job_title: Student IT Assistant in Ithaca, NY
pros:
I learned a lot about interacting with customers, problem solving, and IT related subjects.
Management is friendly.
cons:
There was very little room for advancement.  There were a large number of temps who had been there for several years without getting hired.
They are very reluctant to fire someone, which leads to a lot of dead weight.

pros: Cornell is a wonderful institution with a lot of resources. It is an environment for innovation and excitement, and I thoroughly enjoyed my time there.
cons: The gap between senior faculty and new faculty is large, and closing that gap would be beneficial to a well-rounded outlook.

review_title: Excellent undergrad college with disjointed postdoc community
pros: The resources and faculty at Cornell are excellent. The genomics center in Biotech in particular is very helpful and convenient.
cons: Networking as a postdoc and trying to create a postdoc community has been a constant struggle. Ithaca is a terribly depressing and isolating town. If you don't arrive with a social life, it is very hard to establish one.

pros: Cornell is a great place to work. They really take care of you. I feel really supported here. It's got great management.
cons: Ithaca is kind of a cold place to live and is pretty far from other places. Not much of a night life.

review_title: Good place to be a graduate student.
pros: Collaborative work environment with lots of centers all over campus to use.  Departmental boundaries are a bit fuzzy, but in a way that allows for knowledge exchange.
cons: There is an attitude around here (at least in my department) that you are never working enough.

review_title: Inspiring place to work, reward every day!
pros: Flexibility, independence, intrinsic rewards, prestige
cons: Pay could be better.  It would be nice if opportunities for growth were distributed better.  Now it seems like the same people are asked to do more and mor.  There are more talented people not receiving challenges.

job_title: C E O in Seattle, WA
pros: The Bricks Of Human Is A very Ambitious Place To Work.  You Got To Want To Work Here.  No couch lock here.
cons: Sometime the work is more foresight than the people have to perform.  You will be held accountable for your behavior.

review_title: Fantastic experience working in events and student activities
job_title: Assistant to Office of Student Activities in Ithaca, NY
pros: For a temp job it paid very well; a good first job experience and a great reference for future career opportunities. Wonderful staff-offered independence and guidance when necessary. Treated me like an important member of the team, despite my minimal work experience.
cons: If it wasn't 9 months of winter I would definitely work there again.

pros: Great culture as an ivy. In my department, PhD students get very professional instructions from amazing advisors and we are allowed to take courses freely offered by different schools over the university due to the inter-discipline nature of our research. Good life-work balance.
cons: The location is a little isolated, but it is ok if you want to focus on your research.

review_title: A short-lived job with a lot of potential
pros: The people you work with are for the most part intelligent and engaging. Everyone is willing to help answer questions. The vision for the project holistic and idealistic.
cons: At some points there was a lack in direction. People kept missing various deadlines and at several points there was an apparent lack of communication between departments.

review_title: Opportunities are there if you want them.
pros: You can find work in basically any field you can think of. Most faculty are flexible with work arrangements. If you are motivated, the opportunity to grow and develop is there. You can usually work on meaningful projects.
cons: Depending on your field, time, money, and resource availability can constrain your work. Advisors could be aloof.

pros: Great Research environment.  There are ample opportunities to collaborate with other researchers.  State of the art facility and lots of new things to learn
cons: Ithaca is cold and is in the middle of nowhere.  The upside is that you have nowhere to go but to focus on lab work.  This translates very well to enhanced productivity.

pros: flexible working time. Other than the study group and biweekly meetings have fixed schedule, you can grade the homework totally at your convenience.
cons: Although we might uderstand the concepts thoroughly, sometimes it is not easy to get the students clear about the concept. Involve a lot of thoughts on how to explain, but will get smooth later on.

pros:
- Get to meet a variety of different people, from all walks of life
- Flexible schedule

pros: Always feel useful, get to serve as an intermediary between students and professors. You can drive changes in teaching style and curriculum by relaying students' thoughts and concerns.
cons: You don't really get paid. As in $0. As in this is volunteer work that is extremely interesting and fulfilling, but at the end of the day, non-salaried. This is very unfortunate.

review_title: Excellent place to work, even as a student

cons: 20 hour/week maximum for work-study.  Too much food in the office.  Too nice, feel awkward asking for a raise.

review_title: Top-notch school in the middle of nowhere
pros: This is a top-notch research and teaching institution. Its broad mission (“any person, any study”) and Ivy League status makes it a truly privileged place to work at.
cons: Ithaca is in the middle of nowhere. Plenty of action if one is willing to drive 3-7 hours, but nothing available short of that other than (beautiful) nature.

review_title: Working at Cornell University was a fantastic experience in which I was able to interact with people all over the world.
pros: There was a lot of staff development and opportunities to improve skills.  I was given training directly related to my position as well as training to make me a more well rounded employee.
cons: None come to mind directly.

pros: It is a great honour to work with most famous professors, and apply your multidisciplinary knowledge to help students
cons: It is definitely a suffer in Winter, as the temperature can be as low as minus 40 degree C

job_title: Student Administrative Assistant in Ithaca, NY

review_title: Great place to work...depending on your department

cons: It's difficult to do bad work, which works out great if you don't do much. But it's not so great for people who are hard workers by design.  It's very difficult to advance, especially internally. Political bureaucracies reign, but such is the nature of higher ed.

review_title: working as a postdoctoral fellow at cornell

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ithaca, NY

pros: It pushed me to cold call individuals across the continental US. It exposed me to the potential I have to talk and connect with others in order to get answers to surveys.
